segments.en: Linked Discourses 22
6. Involvement
60. With Mahāli
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

segments.pli: Atha kho mahāli licchavi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami … pe … ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahāli licchavi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Mahāli the Licchavi went up to the Buddha … and said to him:
“Sir, Pūraṇa Kassapa says this:
‘There is no cause or condition for the corruption of sentient beings.
Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.

segments.pli: Natthi hetu natthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;
segments.en: There’s no cause or condition for the purification of sentient beings.
Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.’
What does the Buddha say about this?”

segments.pli: “Atthi, mahāli, hetu atthi paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya;
segments.en: “Mahāli, there is a cause and condition for the corruption of sentient beings.
Sentient beings are corrupted with cause and reason.

segments.pli: Atthi, mahāli, hetu, atthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;
segments.en: There is a cause and condition for the purification of sentient beings.
Sentient beings are purified with cause and reason.”

segments.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, hetu katamo paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya;
segments.en: “But sir, what is the cause and condition for the corruption of sentient beings?
How are sentient beings corrupted with cause and reason?”

segments.pli: “Rūpañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhaṃ abhavissa dukkhānupatitaṃ dukkhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā rūpasmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
segments.en: “Mahāli, if form were exclusively painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings wouldn’t lust after it.

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, rūpaṃ sukhaṃ sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, tasmā sattā rūpasmiṃ sārajjanti;
segments.en: But because form is pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings do lust after it.
Since they lust after it, they’re caught up in it, and so they become corrupted.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya;
segments.en: This is a cause and condition for the corruption of sentient beings.
This is how sentient beings are corrupted with cause and reason.

segments.pli: Vedanā ca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhā abhavissa dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā vedanāya sārajjeyyuṃ.
segments.en: If feeling …

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, vedanā sukhā sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, tasmā sattā vedanāya sārajjanti;
Ayampi kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya.

segments.en: perception …

segments.pli: saṅkhārā ca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhā abhavissaṃsu dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā saṅkhāresu sārajjeyyuṃ.
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, saṅkhārā sukhā sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, tasmā sattā saṅkhāresu sārajjanti;
Ayampi kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya.
Viññāṇañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhaṃ abhavissa dukkhānupatitaṃ dukkhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā viññāṇasmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
segments.en: consciousness were exclusively painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings wouldn’t lust after it.

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, viññāṇaṃ sukhaṃ sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, tasmā sattā viññāṇasmiṃ sārajjanti;
segments.en: But because consciousness is pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings do lust after it.
Since they lust after it, they’re caught up in it, and so they become corrupted.

segments.pli: Ayampi kho, mahāli, hetu ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya.
segments.en: This is a cause and condition for the corruption of sentient beings.
This is how sentient beings are corrupted with cause and reason.”

segments.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, hetu katamo paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;
segments.en: “But sir, what is the cause and condition for the purification of sentient beings?
How are sentient beings purified with cause and reason?”

segments.pli: “Rūpañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantasukhaṃ abhavissa sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, nayidaṃ sattā rūpasmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
segments.en: “Mahāli, if form were exclusively pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, rūpaṃ dukkhaṃ dukkhānupatitaṃ dukkhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ sukhena, tasmā sattā rūpasmiṃ nibbindanti;
segments.en: But because form is painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they are purified.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, sattānaṃ visuddhiyā.
segments.en: This is a cause and condition for the purification of sentient beings.
This is how sentient beings are purified with cause and reason.

segments.en: If feeling …
perception …

segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: viññāṇañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantasukhaṃ abhavissa sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, nayidaṃ sattā viññāṇasmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
segments.en: consciousness were exclusively pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

segments.en: But because consciousness is painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they are purified.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, sattānaṃ visuddhiyā.
segments.en: This is a cause and condition for the purification of sentient beings.
This is how sentient beings are purified with cause and reason.”

suttaplex.blurb: Mahāli the Licchavi reports to the Buddha that the rival teacher Pūraṇa Kassapa asserts that there is no reason for beings to be either defiled or pure. The Buddha denies this, and goes on to explain how it happens.
